repastcity3.environment
Class Route

java.lang.Object
  repastcity3.environment.Route
All Implemented Interfaces:
Cacheable
public class Route
extends java.lang.Object
implements Cacheable

Create routes around a GIS road network. The setRoute function actually finds the route and can be overridden by subclasses to create different types of Route. See the method documentation for details of how routes are calculated.

A "unit of travel" is the distance that an agent can cover in one iteration (one square on a grid environment or the distance covered at walking speed in an iteration on a GIS environment). This will change depending on the type of transport the agent is using. E.g. if they are in a car they will be able to travel faster, similarly if they are travelling along a transort route they will cover more ground.

Author:
Nick Malleson

Method Detail

travel

public void travel()
            throws java.lang.Exception
Travel towards our destination, as far as we can go this turn.

Also adds houses to the agent's cognitive environment. This is done by saving each coordinate the person passes, creating a polygon with a radius given by the "cognitive_map_search_radius" and adding all houses which touch the polygon.

Note: the agent might move their position many times depending on how far they are allowed to move each turn, this requires many calls to geometry.move(). This function could be improved (quite easily) by working out where the agent's final destination will be, then calling move() just once.

Parameters:
housesPassed - If not null then the buildings which the agent passed during their travels this iteration will be calculated and stored in this array. This can be useful if a agent needs to know which houses it has just passed and, therefore, which are possible victims. This isn't done by default because it's quite an expensive operation (lots of geographic tests which must be carried out in each iteration). If the array is null then the houses passed are not calculated.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

getDistance

public double getDistance(IAgent theBurglar,
                          com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate origin,
                          com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate destination)
Get the distance (on a network) between the origin and destination. Take into account the Burglar because they might be able to speed up the route by using different transport methods. Actually calculates the distance between the nearest Junctions between the source and destination. Note that the GRID environment doesn't have any transport routes in it so all distances will always be the same regardless of the agent.

Parameters:
agent -
destination -
Returns:

atDestination

public boolean atDestination()
Determine whether or not the person associated with this Route is at their destination. Compares their current coordinates to the destination coordinates (must be an exact match).

Returns:
True if the person is at their destination

findNearestObject

public static <T> T findNearestObject(com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate x,
                                      repast.simphony.space.gis.Geography<T> geography,
                                      java.util.List<com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate> closestPoints,
                                      GlobalVars.GEOGRAPHY_PARAMS.BUFFER_DISTANCE searchDist)
                           throws RoutingException
Find the nearest object in the given geography to the coordinate.

Type Parameters:
T -
Parameters:
x - The coordinate to search from
geography - The given geography to look through
closestPoints - An optional List that will be populated with the closest points to x (i.e. the results of distanceOp.closestPoints().
searchDist - The maximum distance to search for objects in. Small distances are more efficient but larger ones are less likely to find no objects.
Returns:
The nearest object.
Throws:
RoutingException - If an object cannot be found.

angle

public static double angle(com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate p0,
                           com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate p1)
Returns the angle of the vector from p0 to p1 relative to the x axis

The angle will be between -Pi and Pi. I got this directly from the JUMP program source.

Returns:
the angle (in radians) that p0p1 makes with the positive x-axis.

distance

public static double distance(com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate c1,
                              com.vividsolutions.jts.geom.Coordinate c2,
                              double[] returnVals)
Calculate the distance (in meters) between two Coordinates, using the coordinate reference system that the roadGeography is using. For efficiency it can return the angle as well (in the range -0 to 2PI) if returnVals passed in as a double[2] (the distance is stored in index 0 and angle stored in index 1).

Parameters:
c1 -
c2 -
returnVals - Used to return both the distance and the angle between the two Coordinates. If null then the distance is just returned, otherwise this array is populated with the distance at index 0 and the angle at index 1.
Returns:
The distance between Coordinates c1 and c2.

distanceToMeters

public static java.lang.String distanceToMeters(double dist)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
Converts a distance lat/long distance (e.g. returned by DistanceOp) to meters. The calculation isn't very accurate because (probably) it assumes that the distance is between two points that lie exactly on a line of longitude (i.e. one is exactly due north of the other). For this reason the value shouldn't be used in any calculations which is why it's returned as a String.

Parameters:
dist - The distance (as returned by DistanceOp) to convert to meters
Returns:
The approximate distance in meters as a String (to discourage using this approximate value in calculations).
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
DistanceOp
